I completely agree with you! The soundtrack and sound design of Elden Ring are going to be crucial in creating an immersive and atmospheric experience. A dark, haunting, and atmospheric score can elevate the game's narrative and world to a whole new level, and I'm hoping that the soundtrack will be a mix of orchestral and choral pieces that perfectly complement the game's tone and atmosphere.

The use of creepy ambient sounds, like whispers, creaks, and howls, can add an extra layer of tension and fear to the gameplay experience, making it even more unsettling and unnerving. I'm also hoping that the soundtrack will be dynamic, with the music adapting to the player's actions and progress through the game.

The sound design is also going to be crucial in creating an immersive experience. Detailed and realistic sound effects can make the game's world feel more alive and realistic, and the use of 3D audio can add a sense of depth and space to the game's world. I'm expecting the sound effects to be highly detailed, from the clash of swords to the creaking of doors, and I'm hoping that the sound design will be used to create a sense of tension and fear.

I'm also curious to see how the soundtrack and sound design will be used to convey the game's themes and narrative. For example, will the music and sound effects be used to hint at the game's mysteries and secrets, or will they be used to create a sense of unease and uncertainty? How will the soundtrack and sound design be used to convey the game's tone and atmosphere, and how will they evolve as the player progresses through the game?

Overall, I think the soundtrack and sound design of Elden Ring have the potential to be truly exceptional, and I'm excited to see how they will be used to create an immersive and atmospheric experience.
